utterances.text_en: When the doors are opened and the silk veils in front of them are drawn aside, the sky is revealed. See in their rows and tiers, some more inside, others more outside, very beautiful vessels of artifice and price, some of gold, others of silver, stones, crystals, crystalline glass and other gilded metals, that all together reverberate and dazzle the eyes, It inflames the soul and puts love and reverence in it together, which makes then as naturally or supernaturally, which is the most certain thing, to bow the knee, to bring down the body to the earth, I do not know where to enter or where to leave in so many copies of heavenly treasures. To say in particular of each relic or reliquary, although I do not do but as a litany of them, long business. If I bewitch them and wrap them in a universality, I do wrong to them and to those who wish to know what is found here. The remedy will be to throw them out of the way, neither to silence them nor to tell them. Tell them by their genres and silence them in particular, except for some that could not be concealed so much for their esteem, reverence, greatness and all in passing, with the usual brevity.

Y porque de todo punto quedase colmado este único santuario y gloria de la piedad de Felipe Segundo con los tesoros y riquezas del cielo, con sumo secreto y de años atrás había el prudentísimo monarca alcanzado licencia, privilegios y breves de los sumos pontífices para sacar por las más lícitas y santas maneras que pudiese, de toda Alemania, reliquias de todos los santos de cualquier iglesia o monasterio que quisiesen condescender a sus peticiones y de cualquier tamaño o grandeza, aunque fuesen cuerpos enteros de santos. And because this unique sanctuary and glory of the piety of Philip the Second was filled with the treasures and riches of heaven, with the utmost secrecy and years ago the most prudent monarch had obtained license, privileges and briefs from the supreme pontiffs to take by the most lawful and holy ways he could, from all over Germany, relics of all the saints of any church or monastery that wanted to condescend to his requests and of any size or grandeur, even if they were whole bodies of saints. And here, because many of them were not venerated in the places where they were with the decency that was reason, and because of the danger they ran in coming into the hands of heretics, who as so much on the side of the enemy of God, make bloody war on their saints.

utterances.text: Esto me recuerda un montón que no me lo de hecho es un libro que me he querido comprar muchas. Lo publicaron el año pasado, hace dos ya, que sobre la biblioteca de Hernando de Colón. Y es muy gracioso como José de Sigüenza describe la obsesión de Felipe Segundo. No es maravilla se haya juntado aquí tan incomparable tesoro. Porque si miramos el poder de un príncipe tan grande como el de Felipe Segundo y la gran devoción que a las reliquias de los santos tenía, la codicia con que las mandaba a buscar por todo el mundo, la avaricia santa con que las guardaba, la voluntad y el deseo con que los papas y otros muchos príncipes eclesiásticos y seculares acudieron a servirle en esto será fácil creer lo que hemos dicho. Así abulto y atropellado. O sea, la codicia y la avaricia santa.
utterances.text_en: Your own criteria, of course. Yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes. But then, well, this is how you receive, how you celebrate the reception and then how you organize your collection. But the obsession, that is to say, the reverse of that is not even the reverse, it's like something that is already given in collecting. It's the obsession, maybe a little bit unhealthy. And it is very funny how José de Sigüenza describes Felipe Segundo's obsession. It is no wonder that such an incomparable treasure has been gathered here. For if we look at the power of a prince as great as Philip the Second and the great devotion he had for the relics of the saints, the greed with which he sent for them all over the world, the holy avarice with which he kept them, the will and desire with which the popes and many other ecclesiastical and secular princes came to serve him in this, it will be easy to believe what we have said. Thus abulto and run over. That is, greed and holy avarice.

Solo la puedes mirar, exhibir y recibir.
utterances.text_en: Holy greed. No, no, no, no, of course, because he was a greedy Felipe Segundo. And how he lived badly with this obsession and how he lived with the constant need to control. Because what do you do with a collection that you don't put into practice? You can only look at it, exhibit it and receive it.

utterances.speaker: A
utterances.text: Y te da satisfacción el hecho de que exista.

That is to say, it is this thing.
